f6_assessments.q0:
Monetising a Wikipedia-like platform would be a great way to boost knowledge management all over the world. 
As someone who had a great help from Wikipedia in writing a thesis, I know what the value of open access to such a knowledgebase is worth. 
What I don't see in the proposal, though is how exactly this monetisation/tokenisation would occur. Which is kind of important. 
In addition, the reason for this low score is that it is not in the correct challenge. 
Great idea, though.
f6_assessments.q1: There is mention of legal solutions, yet the solutions are not provided in the proposal. that alone is a big burden on the feasibility. Chances of success would be much higher if this we're to be addressed.
f6_assessments.q2:
It is noticable that the proposal was somewhat rushed. The plan is laid out, but lacks some critical details as to how precisely this would come to be. Besides that the is no explanation why the requested fund is 10K USD when the stated budget is 6K USD. 
Providing details like these in the future would greatly increase the proposal's chances.

f6_assessments.q0:
I can see what the proposer is trying to achieve. A decentralised store of knowledge focussed on allowing developing countries to use innovation and at the same time link to the originator of the idea in order that they can be rewarded in some way, or at least recognised.

The proposal does not include how it plans to replace global patent protection. The largest economies in the world currently use the system but I do not understand how the SOIL data will replace it. The proposal assumes that patents are the motivation that funds ideas, but I would assert that patents are rather a necessary by product of protecting an investment which is only made because of a promise of future cash flows. Without the strong legal backing of a patent system, the promise of future cash flows is less sure, and therefore some innovations would never have been funded in the first place (e.g. iphone).

I agree with the goals of the proposal, but I cannot see it addressing the challenge unless modified to work with an existing global system e.g. SOIL could provide favourable patent licensing terms for developing countries.

I think the proposer may miss the link between the funders of innovation (it's very expensive with no promise of return) and the security that a patent provides them, so working within the system may be a better outcome for an initiative like SOIL.
f6_assessments.q1:
I like the proposal very much, but the current societal and corporate apparatus that surrounds investment in innovation and global IP protection would not be replaceable by a database without the legal and corporate backing of millions of IP owners. The proposal talks about kickbacks to "Idea Owners" but who checks that an "idea" does not infringe on an existing patent? Patent law is incredible complex.

Perhaps this project could work with the backing of patent offices and law firms, however there is no mention of how this might work in the proposal.
f6_assessments.q2:
The patent and legal apparatus required to audit the progress has not been mentioned in the proposal.

Without it, a user of a SOIL idea only opens themselves up for patent infringement and potential litigation.
